The dam itself seems to be built well enough, but its location/gypsum foundation is the primary driver of collapse risk. I considered the following factors in assessing the current risk and how that risk will change by 1 January 2018.  1)  Grouting (injecting void filling material below the dam to decrease the permeability of the dam's foundation)
2)  Lowering of the hydraulic head (water level of the reservoir contained by the dam)
3)  Integrity of the structure
4)  Snow melt in eastern Turkey
5)  Possible military action against the dam 1)  According to a geologist I talked to, grouting is a common design element of dam construction. So the existence of a grouting regimen is nothing abnormal. The design of the grout curtain/blanket is key to its effectiveness however, and its primary purpose is to slow the velocity of water seeping through and around a dam (all dams are permeable to some extent). The quicker the flow, the more energy the water has to carry away material, which equates to a higher volume of material and individual particles of larger size being transported away from the foundation. Reading the New Yorker article cited below it seems the grout curtain at the Mosul Dam is being applied haphazardly, but the key fault many geologist find with it is actually its design, not its implementation. So the hundred thousand tons of grout used at the dam to date is almost certainly helping, but it's not as effective as it otherwise could be. 2)  Lowering of the hydraulic head decreases pressure on the dam (and also decreases electricity generation) in a linear fashion according to Darcy’s law. Currently, the hydraulic head is 90% lower than it was in 2005, meaning at this point the dam is not even generating significant electricity (which has other implications for the local power grid and for flood control downstream). This has significantly decreased the pressure on the dam structure itself and the velocity of the seepage, but erosion of the dam's foundation can still cause its collapse. 3)  Due to the aggressive erosion of the gypsum foundation, the Mosul Dam has been subject to abnormal movement/shifting, some of which is described in the New Yorker article. However, the lowering of the reservoir described above has probably helped preserve the structure. Again, collapse of the dam will likely come from below, not failure of the structure itself. 4)  The most dangerous time period for the Mosul Dam is the spring, as snow melt flowing into the Tigris floods the reservoir. This usually peaks in March/April/May (see USGS report, page 20, figure 9). Given the already low hydraulic head, the fact that one of the two control gates is still working, and the second is supposed to be repaired under the current maintenance contract with Italian firm Trevi, it would take a truly record snow melt to accelerate foundation erosion to the point of causing the dam's collapse. I found no evidence of abnormally high precipitation this winter in the Tigris river basin north of Mosul. 5)  Rather than natural causes, the dam could be destroyed by a military attack. In 2014, ISIS briefly took control of the dam for five days, and other military operations have since been attempted. While the dam is currently under control of the Iraq government, the nearby city of Mosul is engulfed in heavy fighting. Blowing up the dam would be devastating to residents downriver, which is the type of destruction and publicity a terrorist organization might relish. Even extended capture that would put a halt to the dam's grouting program could inadvertently expedite its demise. According to the New Yorker article however, hundreds of solders now safeguard the dam. The recent push to retake Mosul city should help mitigate some of this threat. Finally, I will quote the geologist I talked to who said, "The Mosul Dam is rather famous at the moment in Engineering Geology circles, and folks have been looking at it for years ... Most folks I talk to say on a scale of 1 to 10 this dam is at 8 to 9 in terms of requiring some sort of emergency repair. However, since the reservoir level has been drastically reduced the risk of failure is small." Sources:
- Mosul Dam the Full Story: Engineering Problems, Nasrat Adamo and Nadhir Al-Ansari, Journal of Earth Sciences and Geotechnical Engineering, vol.6, no. 3, 213-244, January 2016
- "A Bigger Problem Than ISIS?" by Dexter Filkins, The New Yorker, 2 January 2017
- Stream Gage Descriptions and Streamflow Statistics for Sites in the Tigris River and Euphrates River Basins, Iraq, Dina K. Saleh, USGS, 2010
- Consultation with a professional geologist with 30+ years of experience working on hydraulic projects

There are multiple news stories in different newspaper and web sites suggesting the dam could/might collapse at any time/in the spring. But as far as I can see they all seem be based on the same sources and the origin of these stories all seem to be link back to the same basic facts that were in the public domain many months ago. While this does not make them wrong, and it has always been said that the spring is the time that the dam contains the most water, a known "most dangerous dam in the world" seems much less likely to collapse because there are now so many people monitoring it. The dam most likely to collapse is the one that no one is monitoring and has a fault that no one has yet spotted.

@Alanne wrote what I think is a great post about what it would take to damage a dam like this.  http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/327417 @Khalid has, as well.  @sevedb has pointed out that this is probably the most well-defended dam on the planet.  And I have uncovered information that it has been bombed (by the US, years ago), to little ill effect.  Therefore, I consider sabotage a less likely cause of it collapsing.   My concerns are focused on 
-the lack of clarity about the actual condition of the dam
-my grave concern about the integrity of the dam that was triggered when I read that a whole segment of the dam has sunk significantly and that so long as one of the outflow gates is malfunctioning, the integrity of the dam is impacted when there's outflow through the other gate.  See http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/409902
-my lack of confidence that engineering science will prevail when there's political pressure to allow the water level in the dam to rise There's several things that remain open questions for me:
-theoretically, at some point won't the dam become "safe" because all of the soluble rock has been replaced with concrete?  How long will it be before that point is reached?
-if there's not going to be any warning of imminent collapse, why are they doing pressure tests, monitoring seepage, comparing satellite photos, etc?
-isn't it possible that a significantly smaller blast than would otherwise be required to cause a dam of this size and composition to collapse could trigger such an event because the dam has less structural integrity than it should? Reading through "top" comments, I noted two points that other forecasters have made:  1)  if ISIS thought it could destroy the dam, would it fight so hard to defend Mosul?  2)  Nobody is moving out of the flood zone.   I also note that there seems to be agreement that the only sure solution is to build another dam, downstream.  Yet, this plan is drawing little attention and no funding.  Wouldn't the IMF be loaning money for this purpose if they thought that the Mosul dam really was going to fail soon? I'm talking myself out of my 50% forecast . . . lowering it to 40%.

(The State Department has refused to make the report public.) It was the fourth time the dam had moved since November, 2015. To engineers, uneven movement of a dam means that the ground underneath may be falling away; the uneven pressure could ultimately cause a breach. . . .  the dam’s overseer, said that the dam was merely “settling” into the earth. But most dams stop settling within a few months after they are built. Outside experts, including Ansari, told me that for the dam to move that much was highly irregular. “That’s more than it’s moved in thirty years,” he said. Alwash, the Iraqi civil engineer, told me, “Something has changed. The underlying soil is readjusting itself because of the voids.”

A second report, also kept from the public, was equally alarming. Like the first, it concluded that sections of the dam were moving unevenly, that water was passing through the foundation rapidly, and that water downstream contained high concentrations of dissolved gypsum—evidence of large voids.

8)  Nadhir al-Ansari, the engineer who made the first inspection of the Mosul Dam, . . . 9)  The Italian team of engineers from Trevi S.p.A,'s main task is to install updated equipment designed to fill the voids beneath the dam more precisely, and to repair the broken control gate. A few clarifications and thoughts. I keep hearing about terrorism and ISIS trying to attack the dam.  This dam is basically a massive hill made from dirt, about 370 feet tall, 2 miles long, crest is about 35 feet wide, base is something like a half mile wide (i.e., front to back).  The reservoir is being kept significantly below full, thus terrorists would need to remove hundreds of feet wide, and maybe a hundred feet deep of dirt.  With explosives that you can move by truck?  That isn't going to happen.   ISIS could create indirect damage that would further endanger the dam, such as killing engineers and technicians, or destroying more equipment, etc.  But the dam?  No. Next, why is the dam now safe?  They have lowered the level of the reservoir behind the dam to safe levels.  Thus, this year odds of failure are minuscule. Why is the dam going to be in danger next year (specifically, spring)?  Two issues - water inflow and condition of the dam.  One - spring floods tend to fill the Mosul dam reservoir at levels that cannot be controlled (see part Two).  Two (part A), one of the two outlet gates remains broken.  I don't totally know why, but the two gates are designed to work together to minimize erosion of the dam.  However, they have been using only 1 gate for the last few years, and so far have not been able to get the other gate working.  Two (Part B) is that they are STILL not doing maintenance on the dam (as per an excellent article found by @Raahul_Kumar, http://pure.ltu.se/portal/files/107014510/Mosul_Dam_the_Full_Story_Engineering_Problems.pdf), dated last month.  The issue is that in 2014 the engineers and technicians were killed by ISIS or fled, the equipment for pumping grout (cement) was destroyed by ISIS, and even though Iraq captured the dam, ISIS has kept control of the cement plant.  When you need tens to hundreds of tons of cement in one pour, every day, 24/7, you don't do that with sakrete (i.e., Home Depot). Murphy continues to control the Mosul dam.  For the many humans in Iraq, I hope the Italians and Iraqis can get the upper hand.

Dams collapse.  Not that often though.  Dams also seem to collapse in the late fall and spring.  Dams collapse for a variety of reasons.  Poor maintenance, extreme inflow, earthquakes, geological instability, and poor construction a few reasons for Dam collapsing.  Dams have also collapsed by deliberate means.  The British in World War 2 bombed several Dams under code name Operation Chastise.  The Mosul Dam is an interesting study.  This Dam is located in a conflict zone, it has been poorly maintained, and it was built on porous earth.  I asked a former employee of the Bureau of Reclamation and he said the Mosul Dam reminded him of the Teton Dam that collapsed in June 1976.  Both the Teton and the Mosul Dams are earth-fill type Dams with very porous foundations.    There is a law called Darcy’s Law it describes the flow of fluids through porous mediums. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darcy%27s_law  I first read about this law while researching the Teton Dam failure http://web.mst.edu/~rogersda/teton_dam/Background%20on%20Teton%20Dam%20Failure.pdf  Once “effective stress” has occurred the Mosul Dam should collapse.  Effective stress would occur when enough water has filled the Mosul Reservoir and that pressure forces water through the porous sediment then causing the collapse. Recently the Mosul Dam has reported that the water levels are down and there is less risk for collapse.  I give the natural occurrence for the Mosul Dam to collapse within the next year below 10%.   There is, however, sabotage considerations.  Turkey is just now completing the Ilisu Dam located just north of the Mosul Dam on the Turkish side of the border.  This means water flow to the Mosul Dam should decrease further.  In theory the Mosul reservoir should just dry up.  As the Mosul area dries up and less pressure is placed on the Dam it would not take much water flow from the north to put Darcy’s Law into effect and cause the effective stress required to cause a collapse.   The likelihood of an intentional Mosul Dam collapse is small but still a possibility. But I bet one or more of the above would benefit from a Mosul Dam collapse.  I can see the Mosul Dam collapsing in the fog of war.  For this reason I’m changing my forecast to 20/40/40. So, assuming nothing happens without cause, why might the photo of the Mosul dam be included with an article about the "collapse" of a Jewish shrine? a) The innocent explanation 1: A simple error. The photo editor pulled the wrong photo by mistake, and it passed through editorial proofing undetected. b) The innocent explanation 2: The photo editor, or whomever the decision-maker was, had no photo of the shrine on file and had a pre-existing mental association between the dam and the shrine, which association centered on their sharing the property of "potential collapse." (This explanation requires the assumption that out of an unrestricted universe of photos [since no photo of the particular shrine presumably was on file] this particular association, out of all possible associations, was considered most informative, or best, or whatever. Quite a coincidence that out of the unlimited universe, this particular association, and our Mosul dam, was selected. Why not other shrines that have collapsed? Or just other ancient shrines? Start with the base rate: annual dam failure frequency (excluding tailings dams) = 1 / 10,000.
http://groundtruthtrekking.org/Issues/OtherIssues/understanding-dam-failure.html Adjustments to base rate:
1. Mosul Dam is an earth fill embankment with clay core. About 73% of the worlds water dams are earth dams. Earth dams are much more likely to fail compared to concrete dam structures. Thus, increase failure frequency by 20% (btw, 27% is not used because I'm assuming that some historic failures were concrete dams). 
Adjusted annual failure frequency = 1/8,000.  2. Assume that most dams are constructed with adequate consideration to engineering factors. Mosul Dam was not. Saddam chose the location based on political factors, disregarding the water soluble geological foundation strata. Assume that engineering disregard is rare: increase frequency by 98%. 
Adjusted annual failure frequency = 1/160. 3. ISIS take Mosul, June 2014. Dam maintenance was discontinued, importantly, grouting of dissolution features and maintaining the grout curtain was stopped.  Kurds and Iraq forces retake Mosul and the dam, August 2014. But, supposedly, the local engineers didn't return. This enabled dissolution to proceed without corrective maintenance, and if not addressed, chance of failure would significantly increase. Hence, increase failure frequency by 80%. 
Adjusted annual failure frequency = 1/32.  4. Known very active dissolution and degradation of rock quality at the eastern abutment. Increase frequency by 75%. 
Adjusted annual failure frequency = 1/8.  5. Positive relationship shown between rate of dissolution development and dam water level. Spillway failure / poor water level management may enhance foundation degradation. Increase frequency by 2%. 
Adjusted annual failure frequency = 1/8 (no change if ignoring decimals). 6. Geotechnical team currently on site and grouting to mitigate sink hole progression. Reduce frequency by 90%.
Adjusted annual failure frequency = 1/15.  If the above assumptions are not totally ridiculous, they imply: 
Likelihood of failure before 01 Jan 2017 = 3%
Likelihood of failure 01 Jan 2017 to 31 Dec 2017 = 7%
Likelihood of failure not before 01 Jan 2018 = 90%

This has been proven by Iraq’s investment with the Italian engineering firm Trevi Group, which according to a government statement will assist in “carry[ing] out the project of rehabilitating and maintaining the Mosul Dam.”
Trevi Group has been awarded $296 million dollars (273€ million euros) to see the project through of reinforcing and sustaining the integrity of the dam. Should a practical engineering solution be put it place, some fear that the estimated cost associated with building a new dam would be closer to $2 billion dollars.

Some forecasts are fun, all are educational, but this one is horrifying.  The more I read the worse it got.  A bit of background. The Mosul dam was built in the mid 1980’s on the Tigris River.  The lake behind this dam is the fourth largest in the middle east.   Heaviest flows along the Tigris river occur in March, April and May.   The Mosul dam is basically a thick fin of impervious clay with earth fill upstream and downstream to protect it.  On top of this is a layer of river rock or other material to keep it from weathering.  There is a spillway on the east side (i.e., used when the dam is full), and two bottom outlet gates (to allow release from near the bottom).  One of these two bottom outlet gates is broken, and if they are not used together, they cause unacceptable erosion.  But, the functional one has been used singly for the last 4 years.  Without filling the dam and using the spillway, the only way to remove water from the dam is electric generation and these two bottom outlet gates.  I could not find out why these gates are broken (mechanical issues, design/ installation issues or settling and warpage).  By the way, bombing the dam would be like bombing a hill.  Terrorists probably couldn’t hurt it.  They could damage a lot of equipment, however. The Mosul dam is built upon a karst type rock foundation.  When you read the term karst, think geology that makes caves – i.e., crap.  It is a mix of limestone that has holes and cracks (sort of like cracked cement) and gypsum (think plaster board).  Gypsum is a water soluble salt, and in the presence of water, it dissolves.  When you put a dam on a river, it creates huge water pressure on the rock around the dam (about 160 psi when full for the Mosul dam.)  Thus, unless something is done to stop it, water is constantly moving through this rock, washing out the dam’s foundation.  There have been huge sink holes opening up in the areas around the dam, I assume where gypsum is washing out.  Huge is defined as 15 meter by 15 meter by 15 meter.  As if this weren’t enough, the area around the reservoir is sinking at about .5 to 1 cm (1/4 inch) per year. This erosion has been dealt with for 3 decades by injecting cement (grout) below the dam from an access tunnel.  ISIL captured the dam the summer of 2014, and grout injection was stopped for a few months.  Upon returning, the engineers and managers found their equipment destroyed, and staff gone.  Thus, even though they are grouting once again, they are not doing so at the frantic pace they did for previous decades. Spring of this year a contract was signed with an Italian firm to manage and fix the dam. Now that we know about the dam, its foundation, the geology, the Tigris’ flow rate, we can make guesses.
The dam will move to less risk over the next 9 months, when it will increase risk once again due to snow-melt filling the reservoir. Next year will be the interesting and frightening one.  Assuming the dam remains in Iraq control, assuming they get the two gates opening, assuming they increase grouting and get control of the foundation, assuming politicians don’t insist they keep the reservoir full (it produces more electricity full, but they are trying to keep it 10 meters below full), assuming, assuming.   The Mosul dam has lasted for 30 years, thus so far, risk historically is no higher than 3% per year.  But, as it is today with current damage, I think I will double that to 6%.  6 months left – so 3% this year.  Next spring (and all springs in the future unless they get the foundation and gates under control) is the risk.  Until they do, doubling the yearly risk once again.  12% next year. It's been a few months since I've read about this dam.  At this point my thoughts are:
-May is/was the rainy season and I've read that the risk is highest then because that's when the dam experiences peak water levels.  But I wonder:  wouldn't it take a while for the high water to erode the limestone?  Perhaps the peak danger is not yet passed.
-I believe engineers are now there working to repair it.
-Some claim that the reports of the danger are just propaganda.
-there's been only the most minimal official warning and preparation for a collapse
-This sounds to be a very unwisely constructed dam, but nevertheless, dam failures are rare, especially dams of this size.
-In this region and point in time I would never discount the possibility of sabotage If the engineers thought that they weren't keeping up with the necessary repairs, I assume that they would create a controlled release.  I'll be watching for news of that. Since this is the kind of question that could resolve at any time, I'm "front-loading" my forecast a bit.

The rainy season has passed for now, so lower risk at the moment (or at least no news in the past couple of months, which may imply lower risk). Could happen next rainy season, although hopefully the current repairs will stave things off. Most likely won't happen for now, which is why I'm weighted towards Nb1J2 at the moment. Note that if it does collapse, there won't be a lot of advance warning, so there's some risk in forecasting!
